result.title: Objective
result.description: To strengthen the capacity of national and local decision-makers to use a national environmental management information system as a means to apply lessons learned and best practices to meet global environmental objectives within the setting of coastal development

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Ability of stakeholders to diagnose, understand and transform information about environmental management into local actions increased and retained;
*% of overall government budget for environmental protection and rehabilitation activities within national budgets;

baseline.comment:
Capacity of the main stakeholders is low and dispersed over many organisations;
* Budgets for environmental initiatives in CI remain low (less than 1% of total government budget spending) due to ignorance of environmental impacts of human interventions;

target.comment:
50% of stakeholders have benefitted from capacity building activity for better use of the EMIS for monitoring progress in coastal zone management (e.g. training and workshops);
* EMIS has contributed to a significant rise in the elaboration of environmental projects (7%), particularly in the coastal zone.

actual.comment: Based on the number of national institution representatives that have participated in capacity building activities (list of presence of representatives/focal points of National Institutions regularly involved in the different capacity building activities of the project), more than 50% of national institutions/entities that manage environmental data and information, and that are key stakeholders in the process of setting up the environmental management information system of the coastal zone, have seen their organizational and technical capacities reinforced in the use of the coastal zone central data base and the translation of environmental data into appropriate information for decision makers. They are also capable to manage the central data base and use it in program/project formulation, on the basis of trainings (19-22 may 2015, organizational capacity building of the platform for data and information sharing; 23-26 July 2015, Capacity building of the platform for data and information sharing on database management with the participation of 20 national institutions) that they received.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Strengthened environmental management information system and associated structures and networks established for improved global environmental decision-making related to all coastal areas in Cote d’Ivoire. To the extent possible: data will be standardized; scientifically sound methods will be better applied; data and information gaps filled; open access to data and in-formation; translation of data and information significantly increases their accessibility to decision-makers; and the financial sustainability of the EMIS is secured.

indicator.title: Indicator 1

baseline.comment:
Since a coordinated EMIS doesn’t exist yet, the number of projects that use it as basis is zero.
Most government agencies retain control over their data bases and sources of information; sharing on ad hoc basis and on demand.
The CNDD is the only high level exchange platform on environmental issues, but there is no specific focus on coastal zone.

actual.comment: 57% of national Institutions/entities managing environmental data and information related to coastal zone have been engaged in the environmental data sharing platform. For departments such as Ivorian Office of Parks and Reserves (OIPR), Ivorian Center to Combat Pollution (CIAPOL), Environment Quality and Risks Prevention (DQEPR), National Commission of Sustainable Development (CNDD), National Agency of Environment (ANDE), National Agency of Urban Sanitation (ANASUR), and IT and Documentation Direction (DID) that are all under the control of the Ministry of Environment an Administrative Note (Memo) have been signed in February 2015 by the Cabinet Director to require the sharing of environmental data for the coastal zone central data base. Other Institutions; Center of Ecological Research (CRE), University Center for Research applied to remote sensing (CURAT), Tropical Geography Institute (IGT), Laboratrory of Atmosphere Physics (LAPA-MF) and Center of Oceanology Research (CRO) have signed (28 April 2015) a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) with the Ministry of environment in such a way to facilitate data and information sharing in the framework of the Environmental Management Information System (EMIS) for coastal zone. Moreover, all these institutions have been mobilized through informative six workshops and nine bilateral meetings organized. This is evidenced by the MoU and memo.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Improved coastal zone management decision-making based on better information systems tested in key area.

indicator.title: Indicator 1

baseline.comment:
communities are not aware of the severity of the environmental problems in their locality;
only 4 environmental profiles of communities have been produced and none of these have lead to changes in Local Development Plans

target.comment:
75% of local leaders are aware of environmental issues in their community and allot proper priority to sound NRM;
all coastal zone communities have participated in the Strategic Impact Assessment by ANDE for the elaboration of their LPDs and are knowledgeable about the environmental activities in their community;

actual.comment: So far we have not yet carried out activities to achieve this output. The start is planned for August 2015. Outputs are expected in 2016 year.
